Graphical abstract Highlights ► Rh-, Ni-, and Ca-substituted La2Zr2O7 pyrochlore catalysts were synthesized. ► High catalytic activity of Rh, and Ca-substituted pyrochlores with time-on-stream was observed. ► Rapid and continuous deactivation of Ni-substituted catalyst was observed. ► Partial substitution of a metal in the lattice creates Oxygen vacancies. Dry reforming of methane (DRM) has been widely investigated, with most studies showing rapid deactivation due to carbon deposition. This suggests a need to develop catalysts that limit carbon formation while avoiding structural changes at the elevated temperatures typical of this reaction. Here, we report CO2 reforming of methane on four pyrochlore catalysts. First, rhodium was partially substituted for Zr in lanthanum zirconate (La2Zr2O7) to give La2Zr2−x Rh x O7−δ (LRZ, x =0.112, 2wt% Rh) pyrochlore. A second pyrochlore catalyst was synthesized in which Ca was further substituted into the La-site to give La1.95Ca0.05Zr2−x Rh x O7−δ (LCRZ, x =0.055, 1wt% Rh). This was done to compare the effect of Ca substitution on the La site along with Rh substitution on Zr site. A third catalyst was synthesized where Ni was substituted in the Zr-site to give La2Zr2−x Ni x O7−δ (LNZ, x =0.112, 1wt% Ni). A fourth catalyst, containing no catalytically active metal, La1.97Sr0.03Zr2O7−δ (LSZ), was synthesized to provide a direct comparison to the substituted pyrochlores. Effects of substitution and kinetic measurements were examined for dry reforming of methane in a fixed-bed reactor. XRD results prior to reaction showed that all the pyrochlore catalysts had a cubic unit-cell lattice. Results from XPS suggested that there were two oxidic phases (RhO2 and Rh2O3) in Rh-substituted LRZ and LCRZ and two phases (NiO and Ni2O3) present in Ni substituted LNZ. TPR of the catalysts confirmed the presence of two reducible Rh species in LCRZ and LRZ, and four reducible Ni species in LNZ. Textural measurements revealed that among the active catalysts, LCRZ had the highest BET surface area (10.0m2/g) and pore volume (0.10cm3/g). Temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) tests indicated different light-off curves for different catalysts, with LCRZ being the most active by this measure. Steady state tests at 750°C using an equimolar reactant feed for 450min showed that the Ni-based pyrochlore (LNZ) deactivated rapidly. LCRZ and LRZ showed similar activity, however, LCRZ showed lower carbon built-up. XRD of the spent catalysts showed that the pyrochlore structure was unchanged during reaction for all catalysts. Carbon deposited on catalyst surface during reaction was characterized by TPO. The Ni-based pyrochlore showed higher carbon deposition (1.4g/gcat.) than either LCRZ (0.26g/gcat.) or LRZ (0.44g/gcat.). These results suggested that Rh substituted into the pyrochlore was more active and selective for synthesis gas compared to a directly comparable atomic loading of Ni. In addition, the replacement of Ca2+ for La3+ may provide improved oxygen mobility of the catalyst (through the introduction of lattice oxygen defects) resulting in the oxidation of carbonaceous species deposited on the active sites on the catalyst during the reaction. Substitution of metals into the crystal lattice might have also lowered the bond energy of La–O and Zr–O lattice bonds resulting in the release of oxygen from the lattice, which probably oxidized surface carbon thus slowing down carbon accumulation. Keywords Pyrochlores CO2 reforming of methane Ni catalyst Rh catalyst 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (DRM): CH4 +CO2 ⇋2H2 +2CO(ΔH°=+61.1kcal/mol) has been widely studied because of its importance as a reaction between two major greenhouse gases [1]. However, the reaction is characterized by: (1) carbon deposition leading to rapid catalyst deactivation [2,3], and (2) severe temperature gradients at high conversions because of the highly endothermic nature of the reaction [4]. Catalysts that have been tested for DRM include supported group VIII metals [5], transition metal carbides [6], and sulfides [7,8]. More recently, catalysts based on perovskites [3,9–11] and hydrotalcites [4] have been tested for DRM. Ni-based catalysts have been most extensively studied for the DRM, with the results generally showing that despite high initial activity, these catalysts are often prone to deactivation due to carbon formation [3,4,9,12,13]. Noble metals are less sensitive to coking than Ni-based catalysts, but they are expensive and have limited availability [9,12,14,15]. During DRM, carbon deposition on catalyst results primarily from the following reactions [3,16]: i) Methane decomposition: CH4 →C(s) +2H2 (ΔH°=+19.6kcal/mol) ii) CO disproportionation/Boudouard reaction: 2CO→C(s) +CO2 (ΔH°=−41.5kcal/mol) Catalysts that can kinetically inhibit carbon formation at conditions where carbon formation is thermodynamically favorable are desirable. At temperatures greater than 700°C, the Boudouard reaction is thermodynamically limited [17], suggesting that it is desirable to operate at high temperatures to avoid carbon deposition due to this reaction. However, methane decomposition becomes favorable at high temperatures, meaning that there is a need to optimize the temperature to minimize the thermodynamic driving force for carbon deposition from these two reactions. Pyrochlores are thermally stable oxides with the general empirical formula A2B2O7 where A and B are rare-earth and transition metals, respectively. Partial substitution at the A and/or B site elements can be used to tailor the catalytic properties. These materials are especially interesting for reactions requiring thermal stability at temperatures near 1000°C, such as DRM. Recently, pyrochlores have drawn attention for applications such as immobilization of fission products [18], catalysis [19–25], and solid electrolytes [26] among others. Although pyrochlores have been used as catalysts for reactions involving methane oxidation [19,27], syngas production from methane-partial oxidation [28–31], and partial oxidation of diesel fuel [21,22], there is little literature on the use of pyrochlores as catalysts for DRM. The only direct relevant work is that of Ashcroft et al. [32,33], which shows that at higher temperatures (∼933K), syngas is produced but the pyrochlore structure is not maintained under reaction conditions. However, this result was limited to two kinds of pyrochlores–lanthanum iridates (Ln2Ir2O7; Ln=La) and rare earth ruthenates (Ln2Ru2O7, Ln=Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd), in which a reducible catalytic metal comprised the entire B site of the compound. The resulting material was therefore unstable under high temperature reducing conditions in the reactor, which led to the decomposition of the pyrochlore phase. Stability can be greatly improved by partially substituting the active and reducible metal into more stable oxides (e.g. La2Zr2O7) [21,22,34,35]. In the present work, Ni-, Rh-, and Ca-substituted pyrochlores were synthesized and characterized by a number of techniques. Here, Rh and Ni were substituted on Zr site (B site) to give LRZ and LNZ, respectively. To compare the effect of metal substitution on the B site along with Rh substitution on Zr site, Ca was substituted on A site to give LCRZ catalyst. Reducibility of substituted metal was studied by TPR. The elemental state of the active metal in the fresh and spent catalysts was studied using XPS. Temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) was performed to study the effect of reaction temperature on product formation. Activity of the catalysts was studied in a fixed bed reactor at 750°C with an equimolar reactant feed. To determine the amount and reactivity of surface carbon species formed during the reaction, TPO was performed on the spent catalysts. Finally, both fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by XRD to study any change in pyrochlore structure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All the catalysts were prepared by a modified Pechini recipe as described elsewhere [36–39]. This method was specifically chosen since it produces a uniform substitution of metal into the crystal lattice [34]. An example of the procedure used to synthesize the catalysts used for this study is as follows: nickel nitrate [Ni(NO3)2·6H2O], lanthanum nitrate [La(NO3)3 ·6H2O], zirconium nitrate [ZrO(NO3)2·nH2O] were dissolved in de-ionized (DI) water. The aqueous mixture of metal nitrates was then mixed with an aqueous citric acid solution. The citric acid: metal molar ratio was maintained at 1.2:1. The solution was then heated to ∼75°C and simultaneously stirred. This process ensured metal complexation. Next, ethylene glycol was added to the nitrate-citrate solution (1:1 ethylene glycol to citric acid ratio). The solution was allowed to stir on a hot-plate until a transparent gel was obtained. The beaker containing the gel was transferred to a heating mantle and heated to 130°C to promote the polyesterification reaction between ethylene glycol and citric acid. This resulted in the formation of organic polymeric network, which acted as a preliminary framework for the oxide material. The precursor mass that remained was dried overnight at 110°C in an oven, and then calcined at 1000°C for 8h resulting in the formation of the pyrochlore. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 X-ray diffraction X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies of the catalysts were performed in a Bruker/Siemens D5000 system fitted with a scintillation detector. The analysis was performed from 10° to 90° with a step size of 0.020°/min. The divergence slit was set at 1° and the anti-scatter slit was set at 0.5°. The ceramic tube with CuKα radiation (λ =1.54184Å) was set up to operate at a voltage of 40kV and 30mA current. Jade (version 9.0) was used to identify the diffraction peaks. 2.2.2 Textural measurements BET surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the catalysts were measured using Autosorb (AS-1, M/S Quantachrome) by adsorbing N2 at its liquefaction temperature 77K. Prior to N2 adsorption–desorption process, the samples were degassed at 523K for 1h. About 1g of the sample was used for each run. All the runs were performed with 40 points (20 adsorption, 20 desorption). 2.2.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy of catalysts To determine the elemental state of the active metal in the pyrochlores, XPS studies were carried out on the fresh and spent catalysts. For this purpose, a Kratos Axis-165 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer was used with an Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV), which was operated at 15kV and 10mA. The base pressure of the UHV analysis chamber was maintained at 10−9 Torr to allow high quality spectra being acquired. For XPS measurements, the pass energy of the analyzer was fixed at 40eV for high resolution scanning. XPS data were referenced to the adventitious C 1s signal, taken as 284.8eV [40,41]. 2.2.4 Temperature programmed reduction of catalysts Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of the catalysts was performed in an AMI 200HP (Altamira instruments, Pittsburgh, PA) fixed bed reactor. Briefly, about 300mg of catalyst was loaded in a 6mm ID quartz tube. Catalysts were packed and held in the tube by quartz wool plugs. A thermocouple was inserted as close as possible to the catalyst bed to measure and control the bed temperature. Before starting the experiment, all the catalysts were pretreated with a mixture of 10% O2/He flowing at 30mL/min. The temperature was ramped from ambient (∼35°C) to 900°C at a rate of 10°C/min. This was done to ensure that any residual carbon species from synthesis (e.g. carbonates) were oxidized prior to the reaction. After this step, the catalyst was exposed to He and the temperature was lowered to ambient and maintained at this temperature for 30min. Then, a mixture of 10% H2/Ar was passed over the catalyst with a flow rate of 30mL/min. The temperature was ramped from ambient to 1000°C with a rate of 5°C/min. After the run, amount of H2 consumed (TCD signal) was plotted as a function of temperature. The amount of metal reduced in the pyrochlores was quantified using a known calibration standard-silver oxide (Ag2O). A known quantity of Ag2O was reduced under similar conditions as the catalysts. From stoichiometric calculations, the amount of H2 required for reduction of the given amount of Ag2O was determined. Repeating TPR of the Ag2O standard gave a calibration curve relating the area under the TPR peak to the H2 consumption. The area under the TPR peak of the catalyst was related to the H2 uptake by that catalyst during TPR. 2.2.5 Temperature programmed surface reaction of catalysts Temperature programmed surface reaction of the catalysts was performed in same reactor as described above. For each run, 100mg of the catalyst was placed in the quartz tube. All the samples were first treated with a mixture of 10% O2/He flowing at 30mL/min from ambient to 750°C with a temperature programmed ramping rate 10°C/min to oxidize any carbonaceous specie on the surface of the catalyst. This was followed by He flushing at 40mL/min for 30min and later cooling down to ambient temperature in He. After this step, a mixture of 10% CH4/He and 10% CO2/He each flowing at 20mL/min was fed to the reactor at ambient temperature. These reactant gases were allowed to flow at this constant flow rate while the temperature of bed (furnace) was continually ramped from ambient to 850°C at 5°C/min. Reaction products (H2 and CO), unconverted reactants, and steam (H2O) were continuously monitored by a Mass Spectrometer (MS, Dycor Quadlink Residual gas Analyzer, Ametek process Instruments). 2.3 Activity investigations Catalytic activity was measured in an AMI-200 catalyst characterization system (Altamira Instruments, Pittsburgh, PA) equipped with a fixed bed quartz U-tube reactor with an inner diameter of 5mm. Stability data was collected at integral conditions and activity was typically measured after about 10min from the start of the reaction. For measuring activity, typically 100mg of catalyst was held between quartz wool plugs inside the tube. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was first treated with 10% O2/He flowing at 30mL/min along with a temperature ramp from ambient (∼35°C) to 800°C with a rate of 10°C/min. After this step, the catalyst was treated with He flowing at 40mL/min, and brought to the reaction temperature 750°C. After flowing He for 30min, the reactants were introduced in the tube. The reactants were 5.5/5.5/89 volume percentage of CH4/CO2/He with a space velocity of 24,000mLhr−1 gcat −1. Activity was measured after ensuring steady state (usually after 15min from reaction initiation over catalyst). All the gases were 99.99% pure and supplied by Airgas. Catalyst stability was monitored continuously with time on stream (TOS, 450min) to determine the resistance to deactivation. Concentration of the effluent gases from the reactor was determined using an online mass-spec (Dycor ProMaxion, Ametek Process Instruments). The mass-spectrometer was calibrated previously with a known concentration of each gas. Reactant conversion was determined as described by Mo et al. [42]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD studies on fresh catalyst The XRD spectra for each of the four catalysts show the expected face-centered cubic unit cell structure (Fig. 1 ). Peaks corresponding to the base pyrochlore La2Zr2O7 (LZ) were detected in all the samples indicating that the Pechini method produces a well-crystalline pyrochlore structure. The spectra for Rh substituted pyrochlores and Ni substituted pyrochlores do not show a significant difference in peak position. This suggests that a low metal substitution on B site does not affect the structure significantly. Doping of the trivalent A site with a bivalent metal induces vacancies in the oxygen sublattice to correct for valence change. Such a modification can sometimes introduce structural defects (depending on loading) in the crystalline structure. This was observed for the Ca containing catalyst, as a perovskite phase (CaZrO3) was also detected in LCRZ. In LCRZ, substitution of Ca on A site also seemed to decrease the crystallinity of the catalyst. Due to the small amount of metal loading in the crystal lattice, peaks contribution from the active metal could not be observed. 3.1.2 Textural properties Results from porosity measurements are summarized in Table 1 . Among all the catalysts, LCRZ and LSZ had the highest surface area (∼10m2/g), while the LNZ has the lowest surface area (∼1m2/g). Highest pore volume was observed in LCRZ, while LNZ had the smallest (Table 1). However, LNZ displayed highest pore diameter, as expected from its low pore volume. 3.1.3 XPS studies on fresh catalyst Results from XPS for the fresh catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . Fig. 2(a) shows the Ca 2p region of LCRZ, which is marked by the presence of Ca 2p3/2 peak at 346.4eV and Ca 2p1/2 peak at 350.3eV, respectively. The peak at 346.4eV may be due the presence of metallic Ca in pyrochlore structure [43,44], however, this peak has also been attributed to the presence of CaO [44,45]. Peaks corresponding to Ni 2p3/2 region are shown in Fig. 2(b), and show the presence of Ni2+ due to NiO at 854.8eV [46]. Peak due to Ni2O3 has been shown to appear at 855.5eV in a previous study [47]. Hence, it is very likely that the peak appearing at 854.8eV is a contribution of NiO and Ni2O3. Another peak was also detected at 850.5eV, which corresponds to the presence of metallic Ni [48]. For the LRZ catalyst, peaks for Rh 2p region are shown in Fig. 2(c). Peak at 314.5eV and 309.6eV correspond to the Rh 3d3/2 and Rh 3d5/2 regions, respectively. Peak at 309.6eV could be due to the presence of RhO2 (Rh4+ species) [49], however, non-stoichiometric Rh2O3 can also be present where O/Rh ratio is in excess of 1.5 in the topmost layer of Rh2O3 [49,50]. This peak at 309.6 could indicate Rh substituted into the pyrochlore structure. In the B site Rh would have a +4 valence. It has also been proposed that aging of Rh particles at high temperatures form an oxidic phase (different from Rh2O3) which is marked by an increase in binding energy of Rh 3d5/2 to about 310eV [51]. This oxidic phase is also difficult to reduce [51]. Peaks for Rh 3d3/2 and Rh 3d5/2 regions for LCRZ were also detected at 314.5eV and 309.6eV, and were similar in occurrence to the peaks observed for LRZ catalyst (Fig. 2(d)). This showed that the oxidation states and type of reducible Rh species in LRZ and LCRZ were similar. 3.1.4 Temperature programmed reduction TPR profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The profile for LRZ shows two clear peaks, a smaller one at 235°C and a larger one at 437°C. Both can be attributed to the reduction of Rh, indicating that there are at least two kinds of Rh oxide species present on the surface of this catalyst [34,52]. The small peak at 235°C shows a weak interaction of this Rh with the lattice oxygen. However, a much larger peak at higher temperature of 437°C indicates a majority of Rh accessible to gas phase has a stronger interaction with lattice oxygen. The presence of a small shoulder on the 437°C peak suggests a range of Rh-oxygen interaction strengths for these Rh atoms that are more strongly associated with the lattice oxygen. Of particular importance in the TPR results is the peak position of Rh specie in LRZ (235° and 437°C) compared to TPR peaks for supported Rh/Al2O3 (108°C) [53] or Rh/SiO2 (81°C) [53] catalysts. These results show that Rh was substituted in the bulk of the pyrochlore and the Rh specie was difficult to reduce, which is consistent with XPS results on LRZ. Results from XPS showed the presence of both RhO2 and Rh2O3 phases. If both of these species coexist, then according to thermodynamics, RhO2 should dominate at lower temperature [54]. Thus, the peak at 235°C could indicate the presence of surface Rh3+ species (from Rh2O3), and the peak at 437°C could indicate the presence of Rh2+ species (from RhO2). The amount of H2 uptake by the reducible Rh species per gram of the LRZ catalyst is shown in Table 2 . The total H2 uptake by LRZ was 1.02mg H2/gcat, which was highest among the three active catalysts. In LCRZ, all the peaks corresponding to the reduction of Rh shifted to higher temperatures. This result appears to suggest that Ca substitution promotes a stronger interaction between either or both Rh and surrounding cations and/or oxygen in the lattice, leading to higher temperature required for reduction. There is also far less reducible Rh in the LCRZ than in the LRZ, judging by the relative areas of the TPR spectra. These results are also consistent with our XPS results for LCRZ catalysts. The total H2 uptake by LCRZ was 0.353mg H2/gcat, which was lowest among the three active catalysts. The TPR of LNZ indicates that at least four different Ni species were reduced. Bai et al. [55] attributed peaks from 230 to 330°C to the reduction of NiO. Rudolfo et al. [56] also observed a peak at 300°C on Ni/La0.98Sr0.02O x catalyst with 2% Ni and attributed this peak to the reduction of amorphous surface Ni. In our spectra, the peak at 281°C can likely be attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO, as observed in the XPS results for LNZ catalyst. Also, peaks at 402°C and 481°C could be due to the reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+ and Ni2+ to Ni, respectively as observed in other reports using Ni catalysts [56,57]. These results confirm the presence of Ni2O3 and metallic Ni phases as observed earlier in XPS. It is important to note that all the peaks in Fig. 2 do not (exactly) match the peaks reported by Haynes et al. [34] for a very similar material. This is likely due to the difference in metal loading (3wt% vs. 1wt% for this study) as well as the presence of a large amount of Sr (8wt% Sr was substituted for La by Haynes et al.), which may shift the reduction to higher temperatures because of a stronger interaction between Ni and surrounding lattice species. No H2 consumption was observed during the TPR of the LSZ catalyst, which was expected due to the absence of any reducible metal substitution into the lattice. 3.1.5 Thermodynamic equilibrium reactant and product distribution Equilibrium product distribution was determined by HSC Chemistry 7 software at 1bar, and is shown in Fig. 4 . This calculation is made by a Gibbs free energy minimization based on 1kmol each of CH4 and CO2 constrained to a gas phase containing H2O, CO2, CO, CH4, and H2 and a solid phase containing amorphous carbon. The results show that gaseous CH4 and CO2 decrease with a simultaneous increase of products (CO, H2) above about 600°C. The graph also shows that the thermodynamic equilibrium of reactants and products do not change significantly after 800°C. This suggests that DRM should be performed at ∼800°C, where the reactant conversions and the H2 and CO yields are at a maximum. The graph also shows that the thermodynamic driving force for carbon formation decreases continuously with temperature. 3.1.6 Temperature programmed surface reaction TPSR for LRZ, LCRZ, and LNZ are shown in Figs. 5–7 , respectively. TPSR of LRZ (Fig. 5) shows that H2 production is not observed until ∼605°C. At this temperature, CO formation begins while CO2 and CH4 are consumed and steam is produced, presumably by the reverse water gas shift reaction. Maximum, in terms of H2 and CO produced, is also reached at ∼800°C and the concentration of these gases (and hence the reactant conversions) become constant at and above this temperature. Conversion of reactants begins at ∼565°C for the LCRZ (Fig. 6) and at ∼740°C for LNZ (Fig. 7). By this measure, LCRZ is the most active catalyst. Although LNZ has higher light-off temperature, conversion of reactants to H2 and CO is complete at ∼850°C for all the catalysts. 3.2 Kinetic results 3.2.1 Catalytic activity and selectivity Product conversion and deactivation behavior of catalysts with TOS at 750°C is shown in Fig. 8 , and the numerical values are summarized in Table 3 . Results show that the apparent CO2 conversion ( X CO 2 ) was greater than CH4 conversion ( X CH 4 ) for all the catalysts. This suggests that there is a simultaneous consumption of CO2, likely from RWGS. LSZ showed no activity, as expected due to the absence of a catalytically active metal. LRZ and LCRZ showed constant activity, and their initial and final conversions were nearly identical (Table 3). LRZ and LCRZ almost reached equilibrium conversion rapidly and showed little deactivation over the time frame of the experiments. On the other hand, LNZ catalyst deactivated continuously with time on stream with conversions of CH4 and CO2 dropping by 74% and 46%, respectively from initial values for over 450min. These observations show that the Rh substituted catalysts (LRZ and LCRZ) were much more resistant to deactivation than Ni substituted catalyst (LNZ). This behavior agrees well with previously reported activities on Rh based catalysts, which show higher activity and selectivity to products as compared to other catalytically active metals used for DRM [58,59]. In addition to carbon deposition, there could be other factors such as sintering of the metal, which could contribute to deactivation as reported by Wang et al. [60]. However, in our case the highly stable pyrochlore structure makes this unlikely because Rh is stabilized within the pyrochlore structure, as shown by the TPR, where the reduction temperatures for the Rh-based catalysts studied here are well above those for supported Rh [21]. The observed deactivation of LNZ appears to be the result of coking. In a previously reported study by Park et al. [23] on A2B2O7 pyrochlores (A=La, Sm, Gd; B=Sn) for CH4 oxidation from 200 to 700°C, the conversion of CH4 and hence the specific reaction rate increased when Sn was doped with Mn compared to undoped Sn on the B site. This phenomenon was attributed to the increase of surface active sites and generation of oxygen ion vacancy upon addition of aliovalent dopant [23]. Although an undoped lanthanum zirconate pyrochlore was not studied here, it is speculated that the introduction of highly noble metal like Rh on the Zr site in La2Zr2O7 pyrochlore could possibly serve two purposes – (1) create oxygen vacancy in the structure, and (2) lower the La–O and Zr–O bond strength [23]. The doping of Ca on La sites and Rh on Zr sites likely increased the oxygen ion vacancy and probably also decreased the bond-energy of La–O and Zr–O bonds [27]. As a result, these bonds break during DRM and oxygen from the lattice is released thus creating more oxygen vacancies in the lattice [61]. It is important to note that even though the lattice oxygen is released from the pyrochlore structure, it is not depleted from the lattice. Although mechanistic studies were not performed in the work reported here, it is speculated that during DRM, lattice oxygen could be replenished by two sources. The first source is the oxygen species formed as a result of the dissociation of CO2 molecule. The other source could be the oxygen supplied by the steam, which is formed during the reaction. If so, lattice oxygen never depletes even during such extensive reducing condition. Doping Ni, Rh and Ca into the pyrochlore structure changes the local structure in the pyrochlore catalyst and possibly increases the coordinative unsaturation of specific La and Zr ions [27] thus affecting the reactivity of doped pyrochlores as compared to pyrochlores without any doped metal. Basicity of Ca in LCRZ may assist in reducing the carbon formation since the high Lewis basicity enhances CO2 chemisorption on the catalyst surface resulting in the removal of carbon by surface gasification reactions [62]. Moreover, basicity also aids in the reaction of steam with carbon ensembles formed on the surface during the reaction [62]. Our activity results are also consistent with the surface area data (Table 1) obtained on pyrochlore catalysts. As discussed earlier, LNZ catalyst showed very low BET surface area and larger particle size compared to LRZ, LCRZ and LSZ. In general, carbon formation is favored on larger particle ensembles. The carbon moves into the catalyst pores and lengthens the intra-metallic bond. Such a process continues until all the carbon accumulates inside the pores thus blocking the access of reactants into the pores. These results suggest that lower surface area was probably responsible for the rapid deactivation of LNZ catalyst with TOS. Fig. 9 shows that the H2/CO ratio for both LRZ and LCRZ catalysts is ∼0.9, which is close to the H2/CO ratio at equilibrium (0.92). LCRZ attained a constant H2/CO ratio instantaneously compared to LRZ, which took much longer to attain the same H2/CO ratio. This probably corresponds to the lower light-off temperature for LCRZ. Fig. 9 also shows that the H2/CO ratio for LNZ decreased with TOS. This result is expected since LNZ deactivated rapidly resulting in lower and decreasing reactant conversion and thus less product formation with time-on-stream as observed earlier in Fig. 8. One contributing factor could be carbon deposition via: CO(g)+H2(g)⇋C(s)+H2O(g) This would explain H2 consumption along with RWGS leading to lower H2/CO ratio for LNZ. 3.2.2 Activity comparison with literature data Table 4 shows the qualitative comparison of pyrochlore catalysts with related catalysts. Due to the absence of directly comparable results on pyrochlores, we compared our data with perovskites, zeolites, monometallic and bimetallic catalysts. These results show that the CH4 and CO2 conversions observed on pyrochlore catalysts are somewhat higher than the values reported in literature at comparable conditions. The data show that LRZ and LCRZ produced higher CH4and CO2 conversion along with a higher H2/CO ratio than other catalysts. LNZ showed poor performance, exhibiting much lower values for reactant conversion. 3.3 Characterization of the spent catalysts 3.3.1 XRD of spent catalysts Fig. 10 shows the XRD spectra of spent catalysts. The pattern for all catalysts showed no significant differences compared to fresh catalysts (see Fig. 1). La2Zr2O7 peaks were present in all the catalysts, which shows that the pyrochlore structure was unchanged after the experiments. No secondary phases resulting from the degradation of pyrochlore was observed unlike the results reported by Ashcroft et al. [32] The results here differ from those of Ashcroft et al. where the pyrochlore structure was lost during DRM at 660°C [32]. These results also confirm the La2Zr2O7 pyrochlore structure has substantial thermal and chemical stability to withstand degradation under severe temperatures and reducing conditions seen during DRM. 3.3.2 XPS of spent catalysts XPS spectra of spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 11 . For the purpose of comparison, the spectra of fresh catalyst are also shown in the same figure. The Ca 2p3/2 and Ca 2p1/2 region in LCRZ is shown in Fig. 11(a). The graph shows that the occurrence of peaks at 346.4eV and 350.3eV was similar in both the fresh and spent LCRZ catalyst. Moreover, the intensity of the peak at 346.4eV also increased in the spent catalyst showing that some of the CaO present in the catalyst could have reduced to Ca0, leading to a higher peak intensity in the spent catalyst. Peaks corresponding to Ni 2p3/2 for spent and fresh catalysts are shown in Fig. 11(b). The position of peaks at 854.8eV and 850.5eV is similar in the fresh and spent catalysts, however, the intensity of the peaks decreased for spent LNZ catalyst. This showed that Ni was neither present as Ni0 during the reaction nor was it reduced to Ni0 under the extreme reducing conditions during DRM. The decrease in intensity of the peaks in the spent catalyst could be due to the formation of carbon on catalyst surface, which hindered the penetrating X-rays, making it difficult to detect Ni on the surface. For the Rh substituted LRZ, however, the peaks corresponding to Rh 3d3/2 and Rh 3d5/2 regions shifted from 314.5eV and 309.6eV in the fresh catalyst to 311.7eV and 307.2eV in the spent catalyst. Binding energy corresponding to these peaks shows the presence of metallic Rh specie in the spent catalyst as suggested by literature [50,63]. This showed that RhO2 and Rh2O3 species in the fresh catalyst were probably reduced during DRM resulting in the formation of Rh0, which was responsible for the higher catalytic activity of LRZ. Similar results were obtained for LCRZ where the peaks for Rh 3d3/2 and Rh 3d5/2 region in the spent catalyst appeared at 309.7eV and 307.7eV, respectively. These peaks also correspond to the presence of metallic Rh [64]. Although in situ XPS study was not performed, results showed that the higher catalytic activity of Rh substituted LRZ and LCRZ catalysts was due to the formation of Rh0 with time on stream. This Rh0 specie was also stabilized in the pyrochlore structure and was visible in the XPS of spent LRZ and LCRZ catalysts. It also appears that H2 produced during DRM reduced the Rh metal in LRZ during the first 30–50min from the start of reaction, which is marked by an increase in H2/CO ratio after 30min TOS (Fig. 9). 3.3.3 Examination of surface carbon species using temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) TPO was performed to examine the nature of surface carbon species on the catalysts. During DRM, the most probable reason for catalyst performance degradation is coking on the surface leading to the coverage of active sites. In DRM, carbon accumulates on the surface primarily due to CH4 disporportionation and Boudouard reaction. TPO results for LRZ, LCRZ, and LNZ are shown in Fig. 12 and summarized in Table 4. There is a large peak for LNZ at 615°C accompanied by a shoulder at 535°C. The presence of two peaks suggests that there are at least two kinds of carbon species present on LNZ. The proximity of peaks suggests that the nature of deposited carbon species might be similar. Swaan et al. [65] also observed a CO2 peak between 600 and 750°C with Ni/SiO2 after DRM for 6h. They attributed this peak to carbon species formed by the Boudouard reaction. They suggest that this carbon could encapsulate Ni, resulting in deactivation due to covered active sites. In LNZ, the smaller shoulder at 535°C could be the oxidation of Ni carbide (Ni3C) species as suggested earlier by Pan et al. [66] on their Ni/SiO2 catalyst, which also exhibited a CO2 peak at 521°C. The second peak at 615°C could be due to amorphous carbon. This designation may be based on a previous assignment [67] on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts where the possibility of graphitic carbon present at a CO2 peak of 597°C was ruled out. Thus the TPO results suggest that for LNZ, the nature of carbon is mostly amorphous in nature (Table 5 ). There are two TPO peaks for LRZ – a smaller peak at 384°C and a larger one at 843°C. The larger area of the 843°C peak shows that this form of carbon species is present in a higher quantity than that associated with the 384°C peak. The peak at 843°C could be the graphitic carbon, which is dehydrogenated and resistant towards oxidation [34]. Goula et al. [68] in their TPO experiments with Ni/CaO-Al2O3 catalyst also attributed the TPO peak at higher temperature (∼700–750°C) to graphitic carbon. The 384°C peak can likely be attributed to polymeric carbon species, which was present in a smaller amount. It is also known that the reactivity of carbon species formed on the catalyst surface decreases with TOS. Hence, we would expect that graphitic carbon observed on LRZ at higher temperature probably formed at longer time-on-stream. In LCRZ, only a single CO2 peak is observed at ∼783°C. This peak for LCRZ appeared similar in shape and intensity compared to the 843°C peak observed for LRZ. This suggests that there is a single carbonaceous specie present in LCRZ, which is also common to LRZ. Quantitatively, the amount of carbon species present in LCRZ (0.26gcarbon/gcatalyst) is just more than half of that on LRZ (0.44gcarbon/gcatalyst) and significantly lowers than the amount of carbon deposited on LNZ (1.4gcarbon/gcatalyst). These results suggest that the substitution of Ca on La sites increases the stability and reduces the carbon formation on catalyst because this substitution creates structural defects in the lattice structure thus providing higher oxygen ion mobility [69]. In the case of pyrochlores, formation of oxygen vacancies could be created due to three factors – (1) nonstiochiometry, (2) Frenkel disorder, and (3) reduction. Migration proceeds via sequential jumps of oxygen ions into vacant sites [70]. Pyrochlores have ordered cationic (A and B) and anionic (O) vacancies, with the A site, B site, O site, and O′ site occupying the 16d, 16c, 48f, and 8b sites, respectively [71]. The oxygen ion migrates from a 48f site to another vacant 48f site from (100) and (110) directions or alternatively from a 48f site to a vacant 8b site and further from 8b site to a vacant 48f site along (110) directions [70]. During DRM, this mobile oxygen probably oxidizes the carbonaceous species, which deposits on the active site of the catalyst during the reaction, resulting in less carbon accumulation on the catalyst during the reaction. The fact that oxygen is not depleted from the lattice is evidenced by the intact pyrochlore structure, which was detected in XRD of spent catalysts. 4 Conclusions Dry reforming of CH4 was investigated on lanthanum rhodium zirconium (LRZ), lanthanum nickel zirconium (LNZ), lanthanum calcium rhodium zirconium (LCRZ), and lanthanum strontium zirconium (LSZ) catalysts. XRD results on fresh catalyst show pyrochlore structure in all catalysts. Results from TPR suggest that Rh and Ni metal atoms are accessible and reducible in the pyrochlore structure. Results from XPS and TPR showed that Rh and Ni were substituted in the pyrochlore structure. Among the catalysts investigated, LCRZ was most effective for dry reforming of CH4 showing higher activity, stability, and a greater resistance to carbon deposition. The Ni-based pyrochlore catalyst (LNZ) deactivated rapidly with time on stream likely due to coking. There was no activity observed for LSZ, which contained no active metal. The activity of the catalysts followed the trend: LCRZ>LRZ>LNZ>LSZ (no activity). Structural analysis of the catalyst post-reaction using XRD revealed that the pyrochlore structure was intact after reaction for 450min on stream at 750°C. XPS of the spent catalysts suggested that metallic Rh was responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity of LRZ and LCRZ catalysts. The quantity of carbon formed during reaction was highest for LNZ (1.4gcarbon/gcatalyst) and lowest for LCRZ (0.26gcarbon/gcatalyst) suggesting that carbonaceous species formed on LNZ blocked active sites. It is likely that greater oxygen ion mobility due to Ca metal substitution for La sites and Rh metal on Zr sites, which assisted in decreased carbon formation for LCRZ compared to the LRZ. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane (DRM) has been widely investigated, with most studies showing rapid deactivation due to carbon deposition. This suggests a need to develop catalysts that limit carbon formation while avoiding structural changes at the elevated temperatures typical of this reaction. Here, we report CO2 reforming of methane on four pyrochlore catalysts. First, rhodium was partially substituted for Zr in lanthanum zirconate (La2Zr2O7) to give La2Zr2−x Rh x O7−δ (LRZ, x =0.112, 2wt% Rh) pyrochlore. A second pyrochlore catalyst was synthesized in which Ca was further substituted into the La-site to give La1.95Ca0.05Zr2−x Rh x O7−δ (LCRZ, x =0.055, 1wt% Rh). This was done to compare the effect of Ca substitution on the La site along with Rh substitution on Zr site. A third catalyst was synthesized where Ni was substituted in the Zr-site to give La2Zr2−x Ni x O7−δ (LNZ, x =0.112, 1wt% Ni). A fourth catalyst, containing no catalytically active metal, La1.97Sr0.03Zr2O7−δ (LSZ), was synthesized to provide a direct comparison to the substituted pyrochlores. Effects of substitution and kinetic measurements were examined for dry reforming of methane in a fixed-bed reactor. XRD results prior to reaction showed that all the pyrochlore catalysts had a cubic unit-cell lattice. Results from XPS suggested that there were two oxidic phases (RhO2 and Rh2O3) in Rh-substituted LRZ and LCRZ and two phases (NiO and Ni2O3) present in Ni substituted LNZ. TPR of the catalysts confirmed the presence of two reducible Rh species in LCRZ and LRZ, and four reducible Ni species in LNZ. Textural measurements revealed that among the active catalysts, LCRZ had the highest BET surface area (10.0m2/g) and pore volume (0.10cm3/g). Temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) tests indicated different light-off curves for different catalysts, with LCRZ being the most active by this measure. Steady state tests at 750°C using an equimolar reactant feed for 450min showed that the Ni-based pyrochlore (LNZ) deactivated rapidly. LCRZ and LRZ showed similar activity, however, LCRZ showed lower carbon built-up. XRD of the spent catalysts showed that the pyrochlore structure was unchanged during reaction for all catalysts. Carbon deposited on catalyst surface during reaction was characterized by TPO. The Ni-based pyrochlore showed higher carbon deposition (1.4g/gcat.) than either LCRZ (0.26g/gcat.) or LRZ (0.44g/gcat.). These results suggested that Rh substituted into the pyrochlore was more active and selective for synthesis gas compared to a directly comparable atomic loading of Ni. In addition, the replacement of Ca2+ for La3+ may provide improved oxygen mobility of the catalyst (through the introduction of lattice oxygen defects) resulting in the oxidation of carbonaceous species deposited on the active sites on the catalyst during the reaction. Substitution of metals into the crystal lattice might have also lowered the bond energy of La–O and Zr–O lattice bonds resulting in the release of oxygen from the lattice, which probably oxidized surface carbon thus slowing down carbon accumulation.
